bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, February 22, 1942

div1.p: Andrus speculates on the location of the original yellow fever charts. He recalls that Reed was quite sick before arriving at Columbia Barracks, in November 1900.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, February 22, 1942
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
2-22-42
Dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
I shall attempt to answer some of the questions raised in your
letter of the seventeenth and write another letter about your
kind criticism of my literary efforts.

The copy of my chart was made by Miss Gillen, immune, practical
nurse who was supposed to look after me. That she had to
call Lambert for anything more complicated than a drink of
water was not her fault. She just didn't know.

I took my copy with me when leaving the y. f. hospital. While
I never compared it with the original I believe they were iden-
tical - they were in general appearance. The original, and
my copy, were on standard Army forms. The columns, separat-
ing DAYS, did not meet Major Reed's requirements. If you
refer to the charts appearing in Senate Vol. 61, you will find
that the frequency of taking temperature varied from three
times a day to hourly. This necessitated special (hand)
columnar ruling and hand lettered headings superimposed on the
printed headings.

General Sternberg's biography contains copy of letter from
Major Reed to the General, of Dec. 22, 1900: “I wish to re-
quest that Dr. McConnell, of the Museum, may be sent down to
join us on the next transport leaving New York. I would
like to have him make drawings of the mosquito and larvae from
live specimens. There is some other work here which he
could also do. He should bring camera lucida and suitable
paper for this work”.

In a letter of Jan. 27, 1901: “As McConnell has completed his
drawings here .. He carries with him a copy of our additional
note with charts. I hope that Dr. Gould this time will
have proofs to you in time so that corrections can be made
before publication”..

In a letter of Jan. 31, 1901: “..I will ask that McConnell
change the period of incubation on chart number eleven to
five days, seventeen hours”..

All this seems to point to the probability that the copy from
which the chart printing plates were made was prepared by Dr. McConnell.
If his drawings can be located, the original charts may be
found pasted to the back. This is common advertising prac-
tice.

Am afraid I can be of no help as regards the windows of the
infected bedding building. I was never in it. During

the day the solid wood shutters were always closed and in the
evening only the screened aperture showed from the outside.

The man I replaced was a private of the Hospital Corps who,
with Hospital Steward John Neate, had been on duty at the Army
Medical Museum. Both accompanied the Board to Cuba.
I “met” this man and that is just about all. He left the
laboratory within ten to twenty minutes of the time I reported
for duty. I had never seen him before and never saw him
afterward. Efforts to get his name from the War Department,
two or three years ago, were unsuccessful.

In regard to illness of Major Reed, referred to in my story:
It is my understanding that the Major had been quite sick,
while in the United States, shortly before. (He arrived
at Columbia Barracks, this time, on Nov. 13, 1900.)
The Major was not very robust. You may recall that General
Truby, in his memoir, refers to the care with which the Major
watched his diet. He died following an appendectomy and,
it seems to me, General Truby speculates on the probability
that the condition was chronic.

Please do not hesitate to call on me for anything you think
I can help on. You have placed me under heavy obligation
and I like to pay my debts.
